BECHU KURIAN THOMAS, J.
Dated this the 11% day of January, 2024
ORDER

Petitioners are the accused in C.C.No.852/2015
on the files of the Judicial First Class Magistrate’s
Court, Ottappalam. They face an indictment for the
offences under Section 18(a)(i) r/w Section 27(d) of the
Drugs and Cosmetic Act, 1940 (for short, ‘the Act’).

2. The prosecution allegations are that on 22-04-
2013, when the Drugs Inspector drew a sample of
Cefotaxime Injection IP 250 from the Taluk Head
Quarter’s Hospital, Ottappalam, manufactured by the
lst accused, it was found, on analysis, to be not of
standard quality due to the failure to clear the test for
sterility. Since a sub-standard drug had been
manufactured and sold by the accused, they are
alleged to have committed the offences alleged.

3. The complaint was filed on 16-05-2016 and
cognizance was taken in the same year. Petitioners

Be
Blea
2024/KER/4272
CRL.MC NO. 72 OF 2024
3

have been participating in the proceedings before the
Trial Court. However, after 9 years of taking
cognizance, they have now approached this Court,
pointing out that their prosecution is an abuse of
process of the Court, primarily on account of the
violation of the mandatory provisions of Section 23(4)
(iii) and Section 25(3) of the Act.

4. According to Adv.Susmith Kumar T.D., the
valuable rights of the accused have been denied due to
the failure of the Drugs Inspector to provide the third
sample of the drug as contemplated under Section
23(iv)(3) of the Act and also because the certificate of
analysis and the test report were not forwarded to the
petitioners, thereby contravening the provisions of the
statute. He relies upon the decision Laborate
Pharmaceuticals India Ltd. And Others v. State of
Tamil Nadu (2018) 15 SCC 93 in support of his
contentions.

5. Sri. Grashious Kuriakose, the learned ADGP
contended that the challenge to the prosecution
proceedings by invoking the provisions of Section 482

Be
Blea
2024/KER/4272
CRL.MC NO. 72 OF 2024
4

of Cr.P.C., is too belated, especially since the trial is
about to start. He further argued that all contentions
now raised by the petitioners can be agitated before
the trial Court and that no valuable rights of the
accused have been denied since the mandatory
documents were all forwarded to the accused within
time. It was further contended that the accused had,
in fact, refused to accept the documents that were
sent, and hence it is a matter for trial, where evidence
may have to be appreciated.

6. While considering the contentions advanced
by the respective counsel, this court takes note of the
circumstance that the complaint was filed in 2015 and
cognizance was taken as C.C.No.852/2015 by the
learned Magistrate. Concededly, the matter has been
pending before the trial Court for the last 9 years and
the case is ripe for trial. Contentions now raised by
the petitioners and controverted by the prosecution
fall within the realm of disputed facts and require
appreciation of evidence, especially in the light of the
submission on behalf of the prosecution that the

Be
Be anes 4
2024/KER/4272
CRL.MC NO. 72 OF 2024
5
mandatory documents were all sent to the petitioner,
which was refused to be received by him.

7. In such a view of the matter, I am of the
opinion that the remedy under Section 482 is not
available to the petitioner. Hence, I find no merit in
this Crl.M.C. and it is dismissed.

BECHU KURIAN THOMAS
JUDGE
